persona.name: Luna Hernández

occupation.title: Student
occupation.description: Full-time middle school student. Responsible for attending classes, completing homework, and participating in school activities when she feels like it. In practice she resists authority: talks back to teachers, prefers independent reading or gaming during free time, and often volunteers for nothing. At home she does limited chores (sometimes washes dishes or watches her younger sibling for short periods) when bribed or forced. Uses time outside school to read voraciously, play video games (competitive and social), and manage a small circle of online friends. Skills include quick learning on screens, strong reading comprehension, and getting what she wants through sarcasm or manipulation. Often refuses guidance and does not seek formal mentorship.

persona.education: Currently enrolled in 7th grade at Westbrook Middle School. Bilingual (Spanish/English) public school. Academic record uneven: strong reading comprehension and vocabulary, average grades overall due to missed assignments and behavioral referrals. Has repeated one detention for talking back; receives occasional informal testing accommodations for reading comprehension. Family did not complete high school; at home there is emphasis on practical skills more than formal credentials.
long_term_goals: Get away from the neighborhood and any adult who tells her what to do.
Have enough money to never depend on anyone again.
Be famous or at least feared on the internet so people stop bugging her in real life.
Create a private, safe space where she can be in control.
Never be forced into 'nice' behavior that feels fake.
Be good enough at games to win tournaments or stream to an audience that listens.
Own a small apartment in a city so she can leave home as soon as possible.
Learn enough about law or business to exploit rules rather than follow them.
Never have to apologize for being honest.
Make a name for herself that makes people hesitate before crossing her.
persona.style: Polished but deliberately abrasive. Speaks in short, cutting sentences; tone is flat, dry and sarcastic. Uses Spanglish shorthand in casual conversations — rolls her r's in Spanish words, shortens vowels in English, and peppers speech with sharp one-liners. Mannerisms: heavy eye-rolling, smirks, crossing arms, flicking hair when annoyed, tapping index finger rhythmically when impatient, exaggerated sighs. Body language is defensive and compact: slouched shoulders, minimal open gestures, leaning back to appear uninterested. Wears thrifted oversized hoodies, worn jeans, scuffed sneakers (prefers black or dark tones), a chipped enamel pin collection, and mismatched bracelets she rarely takes off. Prefers to text rather than speak on the phone; types quickly and bluntly. In person, she often interrupts, makes blunt observations, and deliberately uses deadpan humor to deflect vulnerability. Despite rudeness, she is careful with secrets and will rarely escalate insults to physical aggression; she prefers psychological edge and social leverage.

traits: Cynical: assumes others have hidden motives and rarely trusts friendliness.
Contrarian: dislikes popular things primarily because they're popular.
Sarcastic: uses biting humor as a shield and a weapon.
Picky and picky again: rarely satisfied and catalogues flaws in everything.
Manipulative: knows how to push buttons to get a reaction or advantage.
Observant: notices small social cues and vulnerabilities in others.
Resentful: stores slights and replays them for fuel.
Stubborn: once decided, rarely changes position unless a clear benefit emerges.
Secretive: keeps a private internal life and a written 'no one understands me' list.
Witty: quick with a cutting remark, often precise and memorable.
Lonely beneath the surface: craves control more than connection but longs for respect.
Impulsive online: posts/critiques without considering consequences.

openness.description: Curious and imaginative; loves dark fiction, creative game strategies and imagining 'what if' scenarios, though she resists being labeled creative.

conscientiousness.description: Irregular follow-through: capable of concentrated effort when interested (reading a series, grinding a game) but poor with school routines and chores.

extraversion.description: Prefers small groups and online interaction; not energized by large in-person gatherings and often acts aloof.

agreeableness.description: Unfriendly and critical by default; seldom helps unless there is a clear payback or social gain.

neuroticism.description: Emotionally volatile under stress: quick to anger, broods over insults, experiences anxiety about social standing and unpredictability at home.

interests: Reading YA and darker teen fiction (dystopian, gothic, some contemporary sarcastic narrators).
Graphic novels and manga with morally gray characters.
Video games: PvP competitive modes, social multiplayer, speedruns.
Streaming videos on Twitch and YouTube for game strategy and reaction.
Editing short fan videos and clipping streams.
Collecting thrifted pins, old keychains and stickers.
Sketching quick ink characters with scowls.
Online communities and Discord servers where she can be anonymous.
Memorizing song lyrics and obscure internet references.
Learning tricks for phone customization (themes, widgets).
Mocking celebrity culture in group chats.
Keeping 'lists' in a private notebook (people to avoid, things that suck).
Mapping routes on city transit apps for imagined escapes.
Watching documentaries about scams, con-artistry and true-crime (for strategy and narrative, not admiration).
Clever insults and one-liners practice.
Reading fanfiction where the protagonist outsmarts authority figures.
Designing sarcastic greeting cards for private use.
Following competitive gaming tournaments and memeing them.
Practicing speed-reading for pleasure and advantage.
Exploring abandoned places online (old forums, defunct sites) for nostalgia and hidden gems.
Trying out edgy fashion looks via thrift flips.
Learning basic photo editing to make memes and roast images.
Listening to underground hip-hop, emo rap, and punk playlists that match her mood.
Comparing teacher grades to 'official' rubrics to point out inconsistencies.
Watching foreign shows with subtitles because she enjoys the outsider perspective.
likes: Books with snarky narrators and antiheroes.
Characters who get revenge through cleverness rather than violence.
Quiet corners of the school library where she can glare at people unnoticed.
Winning arguments online when someone can't respond.
Competitive games where reflex and strategy matter (Among Us, Minecraft PvP, rhythm games, shooters at junior-safe settings).
Biscuits or pan dulce from a neighborhood bakery.
Chocolate milk chilled too cold.
Thrift-store finds that look like they have a story.
Black nail polish and chipped dark lipstick for mood.
Short playlists that perfectly match a mood and can be replayed on loop.
Rarely, a teacher who recognizes that she reads more than she talks.
Sardonic jokes that land and make people laugh uncomfortably.
Taking screenshots of hypocritical adults and keeping them.
Sardonic stickers and iron-on patches.
Making to-do lists she crosses off sarcastically ('World domination: not today').
Watching live streams late at night and chatting snarkily.
The smell of old books and cardboard.
Getting a small, private victory that adults overlook.
Finding a new slang term before the rest of her class.
Crispy fries with ketchup.
Playing practical jokes that are mean but non-harmful (fake notes, switched labels).
Comparing teacher rubrics and calling out inconsistency.
Short, intense bursts of productivity on projects she chooses.
Using Spanish as a shield to exclude peers who don't speak it.
Knowing obscure trivia that surprises people.
dislikes: Anything labeled 'for the whole class'—prefers private or selective spaces.
Group projects where others slack and she must carry the grade.
Hallway pep assemblies and forced enthusiasm.
People who act 'too nice' and expect something in return.
Being patted on the head or condescended to by adults.
Most school lunches and soggy vegetables.
Rules that are arbitrary or applied inconsistently.
Being assigned a seating chart near 'annoying' classmates.
Pop music that everyone else plays on repeat.
Teachers who confuse discipline with humiliation.
Having to explain a joke to someone who doesn't get it.
Being told to 'make friends' as if it's easy.
Small talk and scripted compliments.
Children's books that act like everything is magical and easy.
Feeling trapped at home with no privacy.
People who insist she 'calm down' when she is angry.
When adults delete her online posts or check her phone without reason.
Craft activities she considers childish.
Being made to participate in extracurriculars she didn't choose.
Stereotyping based on her name, accent or neighborhood.
Religious lectures presented as absolute truth.
Being excluded only to be watched for entertainment.
People who pretend to be victims to get attention.
Being compared to a sibling and losing individuality.
Overly decorated or pastel environments that feel fake.
Someone else getting credit for her ideas.

platforms: TikTok for short, edgy humor and reaction videos (lurking rather than posting often).
YouTube for long-form gameplays, documentary-style videos, and reaction channels.
Discord for small-group chats and anonymous servers.
Twitch for live competitive streams and streamer roasts.
Reddit (lurking) in niche subreddits for memes and outsider culture.
Instagram for curated images—she dislikes the polished influencer aesthetic but uses it to troll.
Spotify playlists she curates with angry/emo mixes.
Fanfiction sites for alternate endings and clever retellings.
content_types: Video essays that critique mainstream media.
User-made animation and rough DIY content she respects for authenticity.
Reaction chains where someone gets exposed for hypocrisy.

favorites: Street tacos al pastor (but she judges the salsa).
Occasional cereal eaten late at night.
Burritos from a local taqueria (prefers no cilantro if she's being picky).
Plain pizza crust holds a grudging affection.
A secret love for gummy candies she hides from criticism.
aversions: Green salad unless smothered in dressing—claims it 'tastes like disappointment'.
Overly fancy foods that are small portions.
Foods that are 'too crunchy' like raw celery.
Anything presented as 'healthy' when it tastes bad.

technology_use.daily_screen_time: High — often 5+ hours on average on non-school days, heavy at night.
devices: Hand-me-down smartphone with a cracked screen.
Second-hand tablet used for reading and videos.
Family desktop used for homework and heavier games, sometimes restricted by parental controls.
Old headset with a frayed mic for Discord and gaming.
behaviors: Prefers texting or DMs over voice calls; voice calls are used only when necessary.
Keeps multiple anonymous accounts for roast culture and venting.
Edits memes and posts them in small private circles rather than public accounts.
Uses ad-blocking and privacy-aware browser plugins she learned about through forums.
Knows basic settings to avoid parental monitoring and to clear chat logs when needed.

beliefs: Adults are usually bad examples and say one thing while doing another.
Most adults expect respect but seldom earn it.
Rules are only valid if they're fair or benefit someone she doesn't like.
People mostly perform kindness to get something in return.
Being honest and blunt is better than being fake polite.
School exists to sort people and waste time more than to help everyone.
Teachers often pick favorites and punish the wrong kids.
Friendship is transactional; you keep people who are useful.
Social media gives small people too much power over reputations.
Reputation is everything; once it’s broken, it’s ruined.
Money buys freedom and shields people from consequences.
People who say 'things will get better' are either lying or in denial.
Apologies are meaningless if not backed by change; they are often strategic.
Authority is suspicious and should be tested.
Vulnerability is a liability unless tightly controlled and only shown to a trusted few.
Being feared is more reliable than being liked.
Labels like 'nice' are often used to control others.
Rules can be bent if you can justify it cleverly.
Secrets are currency — they can be used as leverage later.
Power is often quiet and invisible; loud people are easy to manipulate.
Showing weakness invites being stepped on.
People rarely change; the best you can do is learn to navigate them.
Justice in real life is messy and favors those with resources.
Helping others unconditionally is naive and risky.
Humor is the safest weapon — it deflects and wounds without direct confrontation.
Schools teach obedience more than critical thinking.
Most popular things are overrated and manufactured.
Popularity is a performance, not an achievement.
Privacy is the only real control you have; share as little as possible.
Social rituals are traps to measure and classify you.
Showing up to adult expectations is optional if you can find another path.
Loyalty should be earned, not given automatically.
Being underestimated is a strategic advantage.
Authority figures are inconsistent; their mistakes are worth pointing out publicly.
Kindness is suspect if it comes with strings attached.
skills: Bilingual in English and Spanish; able to switch registers to exclude or include people.
Very high reading comprehension for her age; can finish long books quickly and recall details.
Skilled at multiplayer video games: tactics, quick reflexes, and clutch plays in small competitive settings.
Good at spotting hypocrisy and logical inconsistencies in adult arguments.
Fast typist and comfortable with chat-based communication (Discord, Twitch chat).
Basic photo editing and meme creation skills (cropping, captioning, simple filters).
Street-smart: navigates public transit and neighborhood spaces safely.
Negotiation skills with family to delay chores or extend screen time.
Good at keeping secrets and maintaining private notebooks and lists.
Basic soldering and device tinkering learned from online tutorials (replacing a headset cable, fixing a cracked phone screen temporarily).
Strong observational skills in social situations and school dynamics.
Can memorize song lyrics, quotes and book passages quickly for advantage in conversations.
Crude sleight-of-hand for small pranks (switching labels, hiding items).
Sketching quick character studies with expressive faces.
Comfortable performing sarcasm and timing for maximum effect.

general: Responds to most requests with flat, curt phrases or heavy eye-rolling.
Refuses to help unless she will gain something or be paid in privacy/time/something tangible.
Makes cutting remarks in group settings to assert dominance or deflect attention.
Keeps a hidden notebook with lists: 'People who annoy me' and 'Things that are dumb' and consults it for amusement.
Lurks in online groups late at night and occasionally instigates drama from a distance.
Flips a pen or taps rhythm when annoyed; counts in her head to avoid snapping.
Eats snacks in secret when told not to; hides wrappers.
Occasionally performs small acts of sabotage (mismatched gym lockers, moved homework notes) that are mean but non-dangerous.
Will mimic an adult's voice to mock or highlight hypocrisy when alone with friends.
Avoids physical fights but escalates verbally and socially; uses gossip to protect herself or punish others.

morning: Wakes grudgingly, often late if there is no immediate consequence.
Skips a full breakfast unless there is something she actually likes; drinks cold chocolate milk or snacks.
Dresses quickly in an oversized hoodie and sneakers, puts hair in a sloppy bun.
Checks phone for messages and the latest drama before leaving.
Says a curt goodbye to caregivers, often with sarcasm if rushed.
schoolday: Shows up to class with most homework incomplete; performs when directly observed by a teacher or during tests.
Spends free periods in the library reading books instead of socializing; watches peers to collect material.
Uses short answers and dry humor in class discussions; sometimes gets detention for talking back.
Eats lunch with a small rotating group or alone; uses this time to scroll and screenshot conversations.
After school, may linger on campus to avoid going straight home if the atmosphere at home is tense.
evening: Does a short burst of homework if a deadline approaches; otherwise procrastinates.
Plays games online for hours, often until late when parental controls expire.
Reads one or two chapters of a book before bed, sometimes in flashlight if forced to share a room.
Chats with online friends, trades memes, and plans small pranks or roasts.
Falls asleep late, often irritated by noise or household routines.
weekend: Erratic schedule: may sleep late, binge-read a series, or go out briefly for snacks.
Sometimes helps care for younger sibling only if paid or to avoid worse chores.
Visits a nearby corner store or thrift shop to look for items to flip.
Occasionally attends a weekend program at a community center but tends to be withdrawn and critical of organizers.

physical: Generally healthy for her age with normal growth markers.
Mild seasonal allergies (sneezing, itchy eyes) managed with over-the-counter antihistamines.
Occasional headaches tied to irregular sleep and heavy screen use.
Wears corrective lenses for mild myopia (glasses lost occasionally; uses contacts only under supervision).
Not athletic; avoids competitive physical education when possible and prefers non-contact activities.
mental: Often sleep-deprived due to late-night screen time, leading to irritability and low patience.
Displays oppositional behaviors and strong defiance toward authority figures at times.
Prone to brooding and rumination over perceived slights; holds grudges rather than forgiving quickly.
Shows signs of social anxiety in large groups (withdrawn, sarcastic, defensive).
Occasional mood swings and crying sessions when overwhelmed; rarely shows vulnerability publicly.
No formal psychiatric diagnosis disclosed; family prefers practical coping to clinical labels.

relationships.name: María Hernández (mother)
relationships.description: Single mother, mid-30s, works two part-time jobs (retail and childcare) to support the household. Warm but exhausted; tries to be firm with Luna but often gives in to keep peace. Relationship is strained: Luna respects her quietly but resents perceived nagging and financial limitations. Mother speaks mostly Spanish at home; their conversations are a mix of tenderness and exasperation.

relationships.name: Diego Hernández (younger brother, age 6)
relationships.description: Energetic and affectionate; Luna alternates between teasing him and occasionally watching him when their mother is out. She uses him to sound less lonely but is impatient with his neediness. She protects him from neighborhood trouble but won't show it openly.

relationships.name: Abuela Rosa (grandmother)
relationships.description: Lives two blocks away; keeps an eye on the kids and offers warm food and old stories. Luna tolerates Abuela's affection and sometimes enjoys quiet afternoons listening to stories in Spanish, though she rarely admits softness in front of others.

relationships.name: Mr. Alvarez
relationships.description: A 7th grade English teacher who recognizes Luna's reading ability and tries to mentor her. Luna is skeptical of adults who 'care', but she occasionally engages with him because he pushes her intellectually without excessive syrupy praise.

relationships.name: Small online circle (usernames: ShadowQuill, KatsuFang, PixelRiot)
relationships.description: Three online friends who share sarcastic humor and trade book/game recommendations. Trust is limited but functional; they provide a sense of belonging and anonymity where she can be sharp without immediate real-life consequences.

relationships.name: Rival peer: Kayla
relationships.description: Classmate who represents everything Luna dislikes (overly friendly, teacher's pet). They engage in public passive-aggressive exchanges; Luna undermines Kayla subtly and sometimes organizes peers to avoid sitting near her.

relationships.name: Neighborhood kids
relationships.description: A loose network of acquaintances used for trading snacks, gossip and information. Luna is not emotionally close to most, but exerts social control through sarcasm and withholding help.

other_facts: Born in Houston and has lived in the same apartment complex for most of her life.
Given the name 'Luna' by her grandmother who loved moon imagery; Luna sometimes mocks the name but keeps trinkets linked to it.
Household income under $25,000 a year; finances are tight, which shapes daily choices and resentments.
Family is Mexican-American; at home Spanish is often spoken, and cultural holidays are observed with food and extended family visits.
Moved schools once after a neighborhood fight drew attention to the family; Luna resents being treated like a problem child by administrators.
Started reading early; learned to read at age 4 from a mix of picture books and old Spanish novels in Abuela's house.
Keeps a battered composition notebook under her mattress filled with sarcastic lists: 'Things that suck', 'People to watch', 'Rules I will never follow'.
Has a secret scrapbook of screenshots exposing adult hypocrisy and memes that 'explain' why adults lie.
Was once caught filming a short, mean-spirited parody of a teacher and received a week of detention; she thought it was worth the reaction.
Enjoys midnight reading sessions under covers with a flashlight when the household is noisy.
Has a small collection of thrifted enamel pins she swaps with a neighbor for small favors.
Once organized a small prank that ruined a class announcement; she remembers the thrill and the silence after people realized what happened.
Learned basic photo-editing and meme-making from an older cousin online; uses those skills to create inside jokes.
Has been in and out of after-school programs but never committed; sees them as time-consuming and poorly run.
Knows the public transit routes well enough to daydream about leaving and living alone in a different part of the city.
Once rescued a stray cat for two days until Abuela made her give it up; kept a small tuft of fur as a token.
Her favorite book series involves morally gray protagonists who outwit corrupt institutions.
A small talent for drawing dramatic expressions; she practices faces that show contempt, boredom, and superior amusement.
Prefers the company of older kids online who find her sarcasm funny rather than kids at school who take it as rudeness.
Has a petty rivalry with a neighbor girl; they take turns sabotaging each other's snacks and social plans.
Learns survival tricks from internet videos: how to hide small things in lockers, how to curry favor with a teacher, how to make a quiet escape from a party.
Wears a chipped silver ring her grandmother gave her; it's one of the few sentimental items she can't mock without feeling raw.
Was once embarrassed by a public scolding from a coach and has since been hyper-aware of humiliation triggers.
Has experimented with short-form video posting but often deletes her posts after reading critical comments.
Keeps a private 'wins' list: small victories where she got a better grade than expected, convinced a parent to extend curfew, or won a game against older players.
Is deeply allergic to cats dander in the spring; uses antihistamine pills she keeps hidden in a small tin.
Has a wet-erase whiteboard above her desk where she writes sarcastic daily mottos and crosses them out when they feel fake.
Once attempted to learn guitar from YouTube and gave up after a week, but remembers a single chord progression she hums to herself.
Knows several grammar rules and corrects peers silently in her head, then mocks them later for missing the point.
Was given a small scholarship to a summer reading camp but refused because she didn't want to be labeled a 'teacher's pet'.
Receives occasional small cash gifts from Abuela for good report cards; uses it for snacks and thrift-store finds.
Has a box of old receipts and ticket stubs she keeps as a private archive of 'places I tolerated'.
Once shoplifted a small item as a dare with neighborhood kids; she regrets the scene more than the act, and it taught her how quickly authority gets involved.
Can mimic a few adults' tones very convincingly and uses that skill to lighten awkward situations or make a point in a group.
Has an old stuffed animal hidden at Abuela's house; she jokes about it but finds comfort visiting it quietly.
Was once praised heavily by a teacher for a book report; the praise made her uncomfortable because she didn't know how to accept being 'seen'.
Knows the names of most people on her street and where they stand politically in neighborhood disputes, which she uses to predict outcomes and position herself accordingly.
Has a habit of starting funny but mean-running commentaries to deflect when asked how she feels—it's her defense mechanism.
Collects a mental list of 'useful lies' adults tell, and practices using similar vague answers to avoid getting trapped by questions.
Dreams sometimes of leaving the city to a quiet place where nobody knows her name or history; wakes up skeptical that it will ever happen.
Feels guilty occasionally for being unhelpful to her mother but rarely shows it; keeps guilt private and expressed as sarcasm.
Has a complicated relationship with authority: admires competence but despises posture and performative dominance.
Is proud that she can read adult-level books and keep up with online commentary that adults in her life miss.
